ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Basic statistical skills, basic use of Stata software.
a basic overview of some statistical principles and some very basic stata associated with it.
Gained basic insight into the kind of statistics needed for quantitative sociology research. Learned everywhere from z-scores to chi-squared to regression lines.
I learned how to apply statistics for my major and how to effectively use statistics within the context of the sociological field.
We learned basic statistic methods for sociology, with some use of Stata software
stats knowledge under the social sciences realm

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Very simple and straightforward statistics class. Not particularly challenging, but decent intro stats, small classroom size and low pressure environment.

there was a lot of wasted time. Section constituted learning one line of stata and class sometimes covered very basic concepts very slowly. It would have been valuable to do more advanced stata and to check in with the class on whether they were comfortable with certain material so they could be a bit more advanced if possible. The testing and psets also didnt seem to test practical knowledge. I would have liked the psets to be longer and more relevant: project-based so as to give us some more concretely transferable skills. Similarly, I would like the final to be some sort of statistics project instead of a multiple-choice exam which didnt really teach us anything. 
That said, professor Smangs is quite sweet and very funny. class became quite an enjoyable time even though I wish I had learnt more.

Strengths: If it was not for Professor Smangs this course would not have been engaging. The material is pretty tedious and uninteresting--it's basic stats. Smangs, however, was very personable, caring, funny, etc making this straight 3 hours of stats (the class has a 50 min section right before the 2 hour seminar) enjoyable and move a lot faster than what would assume.

The course is very well facilitated to student learning and guides the students effectively throughout the learning process. I think the class would benefit from being a two day per week lecture as opposed to once per week.

Strengths: It was extremely well structured in a way that effectively taught us the basics of quantitative sociology
Weakness: Stata was not well integrated into the course (other than having to use it for Psets) in part because the TA was exclusively in charge of running section where we learned Stata, and assigning and grading the Psets. In lecture and exams, however, we never touched upon Stata

Level of stats knowledge covered acceptable and not of very advanced level

Discussion section and lecture classes can be better organized in terms of the the relevance and connection of the two

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you're looking for an easy, low effort statistics class, this is a very easy one to take. It's not particularly engaging because of the subject matter, but it's fun and easy.
If you want a basic stats overview that is a low workload, sure. But I would rather take a course like s&ds 220/230.
If you are looking for an ultra gut QR and don't mind the 3 hours of class every week, do it. If you are a socy major, you have to anyways.
I would. It is relatively easy, and very educational.

Highly, highly recommend the course to any students who need a QR, but aren't good at math. Professor Smngs explained everything in a way that was very accessible, and he was kind and humorous. Furthermore, our class dynamic was really nice, since it was only 8 or so students who were pretty outgoing, though this may change depending on the semester.
It would be a happy QR course
